{{Infobox scientist | name = Hany Farid | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | citizenship = | residence = | nationality = | ethnicity = | field = [[Computer vision]]
[[Digital forensics]] | work_institution = [[MIT]]
[[Dartmouth College]]
[[UC Berkeley]]
[[Stanford University]] | alma_mater = [[University of Rochester]]
[[SUNY Albany]]
[[MIT]] |doctoral_advisor = [[Eero Simoncelli]] |thesis_title = Range Estimation by Optical Differentiation |thesis_year = 1997 |thesis_url = http://www.cs.dartmouth.edu/farid/downloads/publications/dissertation97.pdf |doctoral_students = | known_for = | author_abbreviation_bot = | author_abbreviation_zoo = | awards = [[Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship]]
[[Guggenheim Fellowship]] | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Hany Farid''' is a professor of [[computer science]] at [[Dartmouth College]] and former chair of Dartmouth's [[Neukom Institute for Computational Science]]. Farid specializes in [[image analysis]], [[perception|human perception]], and has been called the "father" of digital image forensics by [[NOVA scienceNOW]].{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/sciencenow/0301/03.html|title=Profile: Hany Farid at NOVA scienceNOW|date=June 2008|publisher=PBS|accessdate=21 January 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/08/11/photography-as-a-weapon/|title=Photography as a Weapon|last=Morris|first=Errol|date=August 11, 2008|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2010}} The recipient of a 2006 [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] and a 2002 [[Sloan Fellowship]] for his work in the field,{{cite web|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/4380-hany-farid|title=Hany Farid - John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|year=2006|accessdate=21 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604010416/http://www.gf.org/fellows/4380-hany-farid|archivedate=4 June 2011|df=}} Farid has consulted for intelligence agencies, news organizations, courts, and scientific journals seeking to authenticate the validity of images.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/23/weekinreview/23marsh.html|title=Proving That Seeing Shouldn’t Always Be Believing|last=[[Claudia Dreifus|Dreifus]]|first=Claudia|date=October 2, 2007|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=21 January 2010}}[http://mynewshub.my/2011/06/24/anwar-eskay-seen-at-apartment-lobby/ Anwar, Eskay Seen At Apartment Lobby.][http://www.anwaraidc.com/?p=13133 US Experts Confirmed Anwar as Man in Video, Court Told.] This is critically important because graphics programs, such as [[Photoshop]], are frequently used to crop and to label figures in scientific publications. Such manipulations can be used to alter or disguise the data. In 2009, after digitally analyzing a photograph of [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] holding a rifle and newspaper, Farid published his findings{{cite journal | doi=10.1068/p6580 | journal=Perception | author=Farid, H | year=2009 | title=The Lee Harvey Oswald backyard photos: real or fake? | pages=1731–1734 | volume=38 | issue=11 | url=http://www.perceptionweb.com/abstract.cgi?id=p6580 | pmid=20120271}} concluding that "the photo almost certainly was not altered".[http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/2009/11/05.html Dartmouth Professor finds that iconic Oswald photo was not faked.] 11/05/09. When the 2012 [[World Press Photo of the Year]] was alleged as being "fake", Farid spoke out against the allegation and criticized its underlying method, [[error level analysis]].{{cite news|url= https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2013-05/16/photo-faking-controversy |title= 'Fake' World Press Photo isn't fake, is lesson in need for forensic restraint |first= Ian |last= Steadman |website= [[Wired UK]] |date= 2013-05-16 |accessdate= 2015-09-11}} He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in computer science and [[applied mathematics]] from the [[University of Rochester]] in 1989, his [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in computer science from [[University at Albany, SUNY|SUNY/Albany]] in 1992, and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in computer science from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1997. In June 2016, Farid, as a Senior Advisor to the [[Counter Extremism Project]] (CEP), unveiled a software tool for use by Internet and social media companies to "quickly find and eliminate extremist content used to spread and incite violence and attacks." It functions similarly to [[PhotoDNA]], a system that uses robust hashing technology Farid worked on developing with Microsoft, which is "now widely used by Internet companies to stop the spread of content showing sexual exploitation or pornography involving children."{{cite news |date=June 17, 2016 |title=Software unveiled to tackle online extremism, violence |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/software-unveiled-tackle-online-extremism-violence-180014703.html |agency=AFP }}{{cite news |date=June 22, 2016 |title=A Tool to Delete Beheading Videos Before They Even Appear Online |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/06/a-tool-to-delete-beheading-videos-before-they-even-appear-online/488105/ |newspaper=The Atlantic }}{{cite news |date=June 17, 2016 |title=Suppressing Extremist Speech: There’s an Algorithm for That! |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/06/17/suppressing-extremist-speech-theres-an-algorithm-for-that/ |newspaper=Foreign Policy }} Farid has been a strong proponent for companies such as Twitter, Google, and Facebook to use this technology to make their platforms safer, and to act as a moral fiber for the content on their sites. {{cite web |url=https://www.thirteen.org/openmind/science/combating-extremism-online/5896/|title=Combating Extremism Online|last1=Hefner |first1=Alexander |last2=Farid |first2=Hany |last3=Wallace |first3=Mark |date=March 3, 2018 |website= The Open Mind, Thirteen |access-date=November 3, 2018}} To operationalize this new technology to combat [[extremism]], Farid and CEP proposed the creation of a National Office for Reporting Extremism (NORex), which would house a comprehensive database of extremist content and function similar to the [[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]] (NCMEC).{{cite news |date=June 21, 2016 |title=There’s a new tool to take down terrorism images online. But social-media companies are wary of it. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/new-tool-to-take-down-terrorism-images-online-spurs-debate-on-what-constitutes-extremist-content/2016/06/20/0ca4f73a-3492-11e6-8758-d58e76e11b12_story.html |newspaper=The Washington Post }}{{cite news |date=June 17, 2016 |title=How to Stop the Next Viral Jihadi Video |url=http://www.defenseone.com/technology/2016/06/how-stop-next-viral-jihadi-video/129210/ |newspaper=Defense One }} ==Selected publications== *Farid, H. ''A Survey of Image Forgery Detection'', IEEE Signal Processing Magazine, 26:2 (2009) 16-25.{{cite web|url=http://dfd.dartmouth.edu/directory/show/350|title=Hany Farid - Dartmouth Faculty Directory|publisher=Dartmouth College|accessdate=21 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627092111/http://dfd.dartmouth.edu/directory/show/350|archivedate=27 June 2010|df=}} *Farid, H. '' Digital Image Forensics'', [[Scientific American]], 298:6 (2008) 66-71. *Johnson, M K and H Farid, ''Exposing Digital Forgeries in Complex Lighting Environments'', IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security, 2:3 (2007) 450-461. *Johnson, M K and H Farid, ''Exposing Digital Forgeries Through Specular Highlights on the Eye'', 9th International Workshop on Information Hiding, Saint Malo, France (2007). *Lyu, S, D Rockmore, and H Farid, ''A Digital Technique for Art Authentication'', Proceedings of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]], 101:49 (2004) 17006-17010. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.cs.dartmouth.edu/farid/home.html Farid's faculty webpage at Dartmouth College] *[http://www.dartmouth.edu/~neukom/ The Neukom Institute for Computational Science] {{Digital forensics}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Farid, Hany}} [[Category:Dartmouth College faculty]] [[Category:American people of Egyptian descent]] [[Category:American computer scientists]] [[Category:Computer science educators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania alumni]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:University of Rochester alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=November 2010}} {{Infobox University |image_name = Logo del Heroico Colegio Militar Mexico.svg |name = Heroico Colegio Militar (Mexico) |motto = ''Por el honor de México'' (''For Mexico's Honor'') |established = 1823 |type = [[Military academy|Military college]] |chancellor = |head_label = Commandant of the Academy |head = [[General de Brigada Julio Álvarez Arellano]] |principal = |city = [[Tlalpan]] |state = [[Mexico City]] |country = [[Mexico]] |staff = |students = |campus = |colours = |fightsong = |affiliations = [[Secretariat of National Defense (Mexico)|Secretariat of National Defense]] |website = [http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/educacion-militar/planteles-militares/heroico-colegio-militar Official] |mascot = Royal Eagle |nickname = |publictransit = |coor = {{coord|19|15|30|N|99|9|2|W|region:MX-MEX_type:city_scale:10000|display=inline,title}} |telephone = |address = |footnotes= }} The '''Heroic Military College''' (officially in {{lang-es|'''Heroico Colegio Militar'''}}) is the major military educational institution in [[Mexico]]. It was founded in 1823 and located in the former Palace of the Inquisition in [[Mexico City]]. Initially designated as the ''Cadet Academy'' it was renamed in 1823 as the ''Colegio Militar''. The College was relocated in Perote, [[Veracruz]], before being returned to Mexico City where it was established in the Betlemitas monastery (today occupied by the Interactive Museum of the Economy and the Museum of the Mexican Army and Air Force). From 1835 the Military College was located in the Recogidas Building (destroyed by an earthquake in 1985). Cadets training for the Mexican Navy originally formed part of the student body but in 1897 the [[Heroica Escuela Naval Militar|Military Naval School]] was established as a separate institution in [[Veracruz]]. The Military College comes under the supervision of the [[Mexican Army and Air Force University]] and the Army Military Education General Directorate. == History of the College == ===Foundation=== Although plans for a military academy were proposed as early as 1818, it would be only in 1822 when such plans materialized, with the efforts of Diego Garcia Conde, the ex-Spanish military officer then serving in the [[Mexican Army]], for such an academy to be formed were approved by the Mexican Imperial Government, through the Imperial War Ministry. In the middle of the year, Emperor [[Agustin de Iturbide]] ordered that the Former Inquisition Palace Complex become the headquarters of the now newly founded Military College of Mexico, the Military Cadet Academy and the Engineers Training School, all under their first director, Brigadier Diego Garcia Conde. By the next year, through the orders of War Minister General Jose Joaquin de Herrera, the Military College of Mexico was relaunched as a separate academy with headquarters at [[San Carlos Fortress]], in [[Perote, Veracruz]] state. In 1824, in compliance with an order from [[President of Mexico|President]] [[Guadalupe Victoria]], 18 cadets of the now called ''Perote Military College of Mexico'', through the permission of then college director Col. Juan Dominguez y Galvez, became the first cadets of the new ''Naval Aspirants College'' and the ''Tlacotalpan Nautical School'' trained to be the [[Mexican Navy]]'s future ship officers. [[File:Mexican cadet.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A cadet of the Heroic Military Academy (Mexico) with a [[golden eagle]], the academy mascot.]] [[File:Mujereshcm.JPG|thumb|250px|right|Another cadet holding the golden eagle mascot. A female cadet stands in the foreground. Both wear the gala uniform of the Cadet Corps]] ===Early years=== In 1828, due to a campaign against [[Secret society|secret societies]] and [[Freemasonry|masonic lodges]], Lt. Col. Manuel Montano's visit became the reason for the College's first loyalty act by the Corps of Cadets and its faculty, for their response to him was that the Military College should be exempted from the campaign due to the fact that no one in the College's cadet rosters were either secret society members nor Masons, and it turned into a national act of loyalty by the college cadets and faculty. As a result of this great deed, the College in March 1828 returned to Mexico City, first in the Bethelemitas convent and later in the Inquisition Palace Complex on July 1. By then, it began to be recognized by every Mexican as the nation's premier military educational institution. The turmoil that sparked in the 1828 presidential elections took its toll on the College cadets. On September 11, a rebellion led by Generals [[Antonio López de Santa Anna|Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna]] and Jose Maria Lobato denounced the election results ten days before, in which Manuel Gomez Pedraza emerged as the winner. Two months later, on November 30, they together with Lorenzo de Zavala and Col. Santiago Garcia staged a coup d'état that took over the La {{Not a typo|Acordada}} building demanding that the election results be voided by Congress. The same day, President Victoria called on the College cadets to proceed to the National Palace, and they fought on the side of the armed forces for 4 days until the fighting ended on December 4, with a compromise reached by both sides. Class would resume later the next day. Political turmoil broke out again in 1840. On July 13 of that year Gen. [[Jose Urrea]] bolted out of jail and led a rebellion against President Anastacio Bustamante, who was later imprisoned in the presidential residence. General Gabriel Valencia then ordered all troops loyal to the President to proceed at once to the city citadel. These included the cadets of the Military College under its then director Brigade General Pedro Conde, who was received by Gen. Valencia and sent a delegation of cadets to the citadel. The College delegation then moved to a church where they fought anti-Bustamante troops, which resulted in two wounded cadets (Juan Rico and Antonio Groso), the former would later die of his wounds sustained. On the 16th President Bustamante left his residence and Gen. Vicente Filisola arrived at the church premises. On that night, when an armistice was made, the attempted coup was already over. The next year, it relocated to the Chalpultepec Castle in Mexico City. This castle would be, in 6 years time, during the Mexican War, a place where 5 cadets and an officer in the faculty died in defense of the Mexican nation, and it would gain the ''Heroic'' designation. After a few years, the College relocated to the Inquisition Palace and later to San Lucas. In 1846, the College's only naval director, Graduate Ship Captain Francisco Garcia began his duties as College Commandant, a duty lasting until 1847. A sudden rebellion by the Corps of Cadets happened during his tenure. ===The Niños Héroes=== The following year (1847), during the first term of Col. José Mariano Monterde Segura as commandant, the [[Mexican–American War]] reached Mexico City and the Military Academy. On September 11 cadets of the Academy were involved in fighting on the Condress Estate. On September 13 Chapultepec Castle and its surroundings became the site of the historic [[Battle of Chapultepec]]. Its Mexican Army defenders, under the leadership of [[Nicolás Bravo]], former President and a veteran of the war of independence, included about 200 members of the Corps of Cadets, aged between 13 and 19. At the end of the battle five cadets - Juan Escutia (who reportedly leapt to his death wrapped in the [[Flag of Mexico]]), Agustin Melgar, Francisco Marquez, Fernando Montes de Oca, and Vicente Suárez; plus faculty member Lieutenant of Engineers Juan de la Barrera; all refused to retreat and died in a final stand as the "young heroes" of Academy legend. An unknown proportion of the other cadets became casualties or prisoners during the earlier stages of the battle. Each year on the anniversary of the battle, the sacrifice of the five [[Niños Héroes]] of the Military Academy is remembered nationwide, with a national ceremony at the monument with the Corps in attendance. ===1857-1920=== In 1858, during the term of Commandant Colonel Luis Tola Algarín, the College moved its facilities to the former Church of Sts. Peter and Paul in Mexico City. During the [[Reform War]] the same year the Corps of Cadets was involved in a clash with the forces of Gen. Miguel Blanco on October 15 in [[Toluca]]. Casualties suffered by the cadets and instructors in this and subsequent actions caused the closure of the College in 1861. The College was reopened in 1867. Located first in the [[National Palace (Mexico)|National Palace]] the College was moved to various locations before returning to the Chapultepec Castle in 1882. Formerly a joint services institution, the College became an academy for the Mexican Army only in 1897, following the establishment of the Military Naval School in Veracruz. On 8 February 1913 the 600 cadets of the Military College played a part in the coup known as The [[Ten Tragic Days]] against President [[Francisco Madero]].Ronald Atkin, page 126 "Revolution! Mexico 1910-20", Granada Publishing Ltd. 1973 Cadets of the separate ''Escuela Militar de Aspirantes de Tlalpan'' (established in 1905 as an additional academy for training junior officers) had joined with regular army units in an ultimately successful attempt to overthrow Madero. However a detachment of cadets from the Heroic Military College, acting on the orders of Deputy Commandant Lieutenant Colonel Víctor Hernández Covarrubias escorted President Madero from Chapultepec Castle to the National Palace on the following day. Termed the ''Loyalty March'', this action is still marked by an annual parade by the Corps of Cadets, attended by the present-day [[President of Mexico]] and his Cabinet. The new government down-graded the role of the Heroic Military College, briefly merging its functions with those of the ''Escuela Militar de Aspirantes de Tlalpan'' and accelerating the training of cadets from both academies to reinforce the crumbling Federal Army. Following the overthrow of General [[Victoriano Huerta]] in July 1914 and the disbandment of the Federal Army, the College was closed. It was reestablished in February 1920 albelt in a new campus in Popotla, Mexico City. Later that spring the then reestablished cavalry squadron were involved in what has been termed "the final cavalry charge in the Americas". This occurred on May 8, when on the orders of Colonel Rodolfo Casillas the cadets acted in support of regular army dragoons led by General Pilar Sanchez under attack by rebel forces in Apizaco, Tlaxcala. In another engagement two days later a cadet was killed in action in San Marcos while supporting government forces. ==The College from 1947 to today== In 1947 The Military College celebrated the centenary of the Corps of Cadets' participation in the Battle of Chapultepec, the finest hour of its history. In 1949, the [[Congress of the Union]] formally conferred the "Heroic" designation to both the Corps and to the Midshipmen's Battalion of the Naval Military Academy, the latter for its role in resisting the [[United States occupation of Veracruz]] in 1914. To celebrate the 150th anniversary of the Heroic Military College (1820-1970), 1 oz silver coins were minted by the Central Bank. In addition stamps featuring two Military College [[shako]]s were printed by the Government of Mexico. A special issue of stamps also commemorated the Golden Jubilee of "the final cavalry charge in the Americas"; carried out by the cavalry cadets of the college in 1920 (see above). In 1976, the College's present campus in [[Tlalpan]] Borough, [[Mexico City]], was formally opened, partially damaged by the 1985 earthquake that struck the city. Today, the commandant of the academy is Brigade General Julio Álvarez Arellano. The school was used as a setting for [[Luis Miguel]]'s 1989 music video [["La Incondicional"]]. In the video he plays an Air Force cadet who is in love, but he must take his stuides as soldier seriously. In a marching scene towards the end of the song one can see the "Por el Honor de Mexico" banner. Perote, the second home of the Military College, has been dubbed by the Veracruz State Congress as ''The Cradle of the Military College'' since 2002. From 2007, the academy has accepted female cadets. The present Corps is regiment-sized and has among its units a cavalry squadron and an artillery battery, plus an armored cavalry training squadron raised recently - a first in a military academy in Latin America. == Motto and Collegiate Slogan == ''Por el Honor de Mexico'' (''For Mexico's Honor'') is the college motto, made in a contest organized by radio station XEQ in commemoration of the centenary of the defense of Chalpultepec Castle in 1947. Every midday, after the afternoon ceremony and before the midday parade, the following cheer is done by the Corps of Cadets: * Cadet Corps Commander: "Heroico Colegio Militar" ("Heroic Military College") * Cadets: ''Por el Honor de Mexico!'' (''For Mexico's Honor!'') == Collegiate Hymn and March == === Hymn of the Heroic Military College === The Hymn of the Heroic Military College was composed in 1930 by Prof. José Ignacio Ríos del Río.http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php?id=234 ===Lyrics=== '''Spanish'''
''Chorus''
Vibre el clarín de la guerra, resuenen las fanfarrias
Redoblen los tambores, una marcha triunfal
Y lleven de la Patria a todos los confines
Tu nombre sacrosanto,
Colegio Militar
Tu nombre sacrosanto,
Colegio Militar ''Verse
Colegio sacrosanto, de memoria bendita
de forjaran sus almas, Montes de Oca y Melgar
La Patria bate marcha de honor a tu pasado,
de epopeyas gloriosas y de nombre inmortal. Y en un gesto sublime de amor y de cariño,
bendice a los efebos que supieron morir
bañados por las ráfagas de luz espendorosa
que el ángel de la gloria enviara del cenit. ''Repeat Chorus'' === Regimental March of the Heroic Military College === The Regimental March was composed by Lieutenant José Sotero Ortiz Sánchez, in time for the College's 1947 centenary of the Battle of Chapultepec. ===Lyrics=== '''Spanish'''
Páginas del libro de la historia del Heroico Colegio Militar
de epopeyas que ya jamás se borran del santuario de la inmortalidad.
Canto que se eleva a la memoria como ofrenda de honor a la lealtad
de los héroes que envueltos por la gloria grandioso ejemplo que nos dio la libertad.
''Repeat All'' Juventud de mi patria sublime, que marcháis con gallarda ilusión
aumentáreis la historia que escribe nobles hechos de sangre y honor.
Yunque forjador de hombres de guerra como Suárez, Escutia y Melgar,
Montes de Oca, Márquez y De la Barrera, los niños héroes de mi México inmortal!
''Repeat All'' == Commandants == [http://www.sedena.gob.mx/index.php/educacion-militar/planteles-militares/heroico-colegio-militar/historia-hcm/directores-hcm Directores del Heroico Colegio Militar], [[Secretariat of National Defense (Mexico)]] (SEDENA) {| class="wikitable" !No.!!Period!!Rank!!!!Notes |- |1||1818–1823||Brigadier General||[[Diego García Conde]]|| |- |2||1823–1824||Cavalry Colonel||[[Juan Domínguez y Gálvez]]|| |- |3||1825–1828||Cavalry Lieutenant Colonel||[[José Manuel Arechaga]]|| |- |4||1835–1836||Engineers Colonel||[[Ignacio Mora y Villamil]]|| |- |5||1836–1846||Brigadier General||[[Pedro García Conde]] |- |6||1846–1847||Graduate Captain, Commander||[[Francisco García Salinas]]||Only naval officer commandant of the College |- |7||1847–1853||Graduate Gen., Engineers Colonel||[[José Mariano Monterde Segura]]||Led the defense of [[Chapultepec Castle]] during the [[Battle of Chapultepec]] which took a heavy toll for the Academy |- |8||1853–1854||Graduate Gen., Engineers Colonel||[[Santiago Blanco Duque de Estrada]]|| |- |9||1854–1859||Graduate Gen., Engineers Colonel||[[Luis Tola Algarín]]|| |- |10||1859–1860||Engineers Colonel (Staff)||José Mariano Monterde Segura||2nd Period |- |11||1861–1863||Brigade General||[[José Justo Alvarez Valenzuela]]|| |- |12||1868–1871||Engineers Colonel||[[Amado Camacho]]|| |- |13||1871–1880||Engineers Colonel||[[Miguel Quintana González]]|| |- |14||1880–1883||Divisional General||[[Sóstenes Rocha]]|| |- |15||1883–1884||General Graduado, Coronel Tec. de Artillería||[[Francisco de Paula Méndez]]|| |- |16||1884–1906||Engineers Colonel General||[[Juan Villegas (general)|Juan Villegas]]||Highest-ranking officer commandant of the College |- |17||1906–1912||General de Brigada de E.M. '''Iládio Amado''' (born 1976, [[Portugal]]) is a teacher of music education and also an instrumentalist and [[composer]]. He lives in [[Vila do Bispo]], [[Algarve]], and has performed all over the country as a member of various bands. He is currently a member of [[Tokamaki]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Entrevista ao músico Iládio Amado|journal=Mapamag|date=18 June 2014|url=http://mapamusica.pt/destaque-mapamag-entrevista-ao-musico-iladio-amado/|accessdate=3 September 2014|language=Portuguese}}</ref>
== Career == === Individual work ===
* '''2014 - Advertising spots for Children's Rights for Radio Fóia, at the request of CPCJ [[Monchique]].''' Two series were recorded for this initiative with schoolchildren participating. The transmission began on [[World Children's Day]] and is to culminate in the organization of 'I Days of Children's Rights', next November.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Monchique|first1=Agenda Municipal|title=Direitos da Criança|journal=Agenda Municipal de Monchique|date=May 2014|pages=14–15|url=http://issuu.com/agendamunicipalmonchique/docs/agendamaio2014|ref=Agenda Municipal de Monchique}}</ref> * '''2013 - Original soundtrack for ''Tesouras e Navalhas'', solo and with Tokamaki.''' This documentary by [[Paradoxon Produções]], directed by Hernani Duarte Maria had its premiere at the Library António Ramos Rosa in [[Faro, Portugal|Faro]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Informação|first1=Sul|title=Documentário "Tesouras e Navalhas" mostra uma das mais antigas barbearias da Baixa de Faro|url=http://www.sulinformacao.pt/2013/11/documentario-%C2%ABtesouras-e-navalhas%C2%BB-mostra-uma-das-mais-antigas-barbearias-da-baixa-de-faro/|accessdate=3 September 2014|agency=Sul Informação|publisher=Sul Informação|date=6 November 2013|ref=Sul Informação}}</ref> The video clip of Tokamaki, directed by the same director, was also displayed at the RTP International, RTP Asia and RTP America. Official Selection of the 1st edition of Portugal Underground Film Festival<ref>{{cite web|last1=Festival|first1=Portugal Underground Film|title=Programa PUFF|url=http://www.ncoisas.com/portugal-underground-film-festival-2012/|website=NCoisas|publisher=Gabinete de Informação e Relações Públicas |accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=PUFF}}</ref> and FICSAM 2013 (International Mental Health Film Festival of Faro); * '''2011 - Original music and audio post-production of the documentary "Memórias da Nossa Senhora da Guadalupe"''',<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rodrigues|first1=Elisabete|title=Monumentos do Algarve também participam nas Jornadas Europeias de Cultura|journal=Sul Informação|date=19 September 2011|url=http://www.sulinformacao.pt/2011/09/monumentos-do-algarve-tambem-participam-nas-jornadas-europeias-de-cultura/|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=Sul Informação}}</ref> directed by Hernani Duarte Maria, Raquel Roxo and Elsa Freixial for the Secretary of State for Culture (Directorate of Regional Culture of the Algarve), presented during the [[European Heritage Days]];<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DiariOnline|title=Jornadas Europeias do Património comemoradas nos monumentos algarvios|journal=Região Sul|date=21 September 2011|url=http://www.regiao-sul.pt/noticia.php?refnoticia=120085|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=DiariOnline}}</ref> * '''2004 - Composition of Children's Ballet "A Celebração da Primavera"''',<ref>{{cite web|last1=Infantil|first1=Ninho|title=O Outono chegou!|url=http://www.ninhoinfantil.com.br/faca-voce-mesmo-diy/outono-chegou/207|website=Ninho Infantl|publisher=Ninho Infantil|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=Estações}}</ref> danced and presented by the students of 1st Cycle of Basic Schools in the municipality of [[Arronches]]; * '''2002 - Composition and Children's Ballet presentation of "O Julgamento do Cuco"'''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Castelo de Vide|first1=Associação de Pais|title=O Julgamento do Cuco|url=https://www.facebook.com/iladioamado/photos/a.213730669172.129730.103180994172/10150611325189173/?type=3&theater|website=Facebook|publisher=Iládio Amado|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=Julgamento do Cuco}}</ref> at the request of the Association of Parents of the Schools of [[Castelo de Vide]], choreography by Maria Alcobia.
=== Bands, collaborations and other projects ===
* '''2011 - Honorable Mention in the Grande © - National Creativity Contest for the Schools''', in Music Category, with students representing the project of High School Julio Dantas of Lagos, as a teacher, coordinator and producer in the Final Ceremony organized by the [[Municipality of Cascais]] and the AGECOP (Association for Management of Private Copying);<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Artistas|first1=Gazeta dos|title=Festa Grande © reúne celebridades em Cascais|journal=Gazeta dos Artistas|url=http://www.gazetadosartistas.pt/?p=633|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=Gazeta dos Artistas}}</ref> * '''2010 - Co-author of the project, along with the writer Bruno Filipe Esteves, "A Palavra Longe de Aberta"''', which rises as synergistic expression and accomplice of the shared passion by the poetry and by the music with lusophone origin;<ref>{{cite web|last1=Teorema|first1=Antes Teor Que|title=Projecto - "A Palavra Longe de Aberta"|url=http://estupoema.blogspot.pt/2010/04/projecto-palavra-longe-de-aberta.html|website=Antes Teor Que Teorema|publisher=Bruno Filipe Esteves|accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref> * '''2010/2014 - Guest member of Jury<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Central|first1=Algarve|title=FINAL: 11ª EDIÇÃO DO CONCURSO DE FADO DE VILA DO BISPO|journal=Algarve Central|date=24 May 2010|url=http://press.algarvecentral.net/2010/05/final-11%C2%AA-edicao-do-concurso-de-fado-de-vila-do-bispo/|accessdate=9 September 2014|ref=Algarve Central}}</ref> for the Concurso de [[Fado]] [[Sagres (beer)|Cerveja Sagres]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=News|first1=Metro|title=Ana Rato conquistou 1º lugar no Concurso de Fado Cerveja Sagres|journal=MetroNews|date=12 June 2014|url=http://www.metronews.com.pt/2014/06/12/ana-rato-conquistou-1o-lugar-no-concurso-de-fado-cerveja-sagres-concelho-de-vila-do-bispo/|accessdate=9 September 2014|ref=MetroNews}}</ref>''', sponsored by the municipality of [[Vila do Bispo]], with competitors from all the country;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Primeiro|first1=Algarve|title=Fadista de Beja vence Concurso de Fado Cerveja Sagres|journal=Algarve Primeiro|date=11 June 2014|url=http://algarveprimeiro.com/d/fadista-de-beja-vence-concurso-de-fado-cerveja-sagres-concelho-de-vila-do-bispo/4266-1|accessdate=9 September 2014|ref=Algarve Primeiro}}</ref> * '''2009 - Arrangements and production of a song composed by Helena Tapadinhas for her book 'Contos do Mago''''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=AlgarveBeCre|title=Contos do Mago: a música|url=http://algarvebecre.blogspot.pt/2010/01/contos-do-mago-musica.html|website=AlgarveBeCre|publisher=Bibliotecas RBE do Algarve: blogue interconcelhio|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=Contos do Mago}}</ref> This theme was produced under the Environmental Education Program for the Arts (PREAA)<ref>{{cite news|last1=DREALG|title=Contos do Mago deram-se a conhecer no fecho do Ano Internacional do Planeta Terra|url=http://www.drealg.min-edu.pt/content_newsdet.asp?newsID=2164&auxID=news|accessdate=7 September 2014|agency=Direcção Regional de Educação do Algarve|publisher=DREALG|ref=AlgarveBeCre}}</ref> and presented at Planet Earth Lisbon Event<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Varela |first1=Ana|title=Contos do Mago deram-se a conhecer no fecho do Ano Internacional do Planeta Terra|journal=Barlavento Online|date=26 November 2009|url=http://www.barlavento.pt/index.php/noticia?id=37957|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=Barlavento Online}}</ref> in [[Parque das Nações]], during the close of the [[International Year of Planet Earth]], promoted by the [[United Nations]] and the National Commission of Unesco;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=123|first1=Algarve|title=Helena Tapadinhas e DREALG - Os contos do mago|journal=Algarve 1 2 3|date=29 October 2009|url=http://www.algarve123.com/pt/Artigos/2-398/Os_contos_do_mago|accessdate=7 September 2014|ref=Algarve 1 2 3}}</ref> * '''2005 - Co-authored, along with André "IGOR" Teresinha, of the sound ambience WAD''', which can be heard as part of permanent exhibition of the Museu do Rio<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clara|first1=Ana|title=Alcoutim - Gentes, culturas e tradições no Museu do Rio|url=http://www.cafeportugal.pt/pages/sitios_artigo.aspx?id=1946|website=Café Portugal|publisher=Café Portugal|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=Museu do Rio}}</ref> - Guerreiros do Rio ([[Alcoutim]]); * '''1999 - RAMAIA<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ramaia|title=Ramaia|date=1999|publisher=Junta de Freguesia de Vila do Bispo|location=Vila do Bispo|edition=Junta de Freguesia de Vila do Bispo|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=Ramaia}}</ref>''', collective exhibition of [[Contemporary Art]] at EPAC,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Amado|first1=Iládio|title=Ramaia|url=https://www.facebook.com/iladioamado/photos/a.213730669172.129730.103180994172/10152695105669173/?type=3&theater|website=Facebook|publisher=Junta de Freguesia de Vila do Bispo|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=Ramaia}}</ref> in [[Vila do Bispo]]; * '''1999 - RAMa'''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Alvarez|first1=Galeria|title=RAMa|date=1999|publisher=Galeria Alvares|location=Porto|edition=Gráfica S. Miguel - Gulpilhares|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=RAMa}}</ref> - collective exhibition of [[Contemporary Art]] at Galeria Alvarez,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Alvarez|first1=Galeria|title=RAMa|url=https://www.facebook.com/iladioamado/photos/a.213730669172.129730.103180994172/10151321712169173/?type=3&theater|website=Facebook|publisher=Iládio Amado|accessdate=8 September 2014|ref=RAMa}}</ref> in [[Porto]].
==Discography==
* '''2010 - [https://iladioamado.bandcamp.com/releases COROLÁRIO]''' - Limited Edition (250 copies)
==External links== * '''[https://pt-pt.facebook.com/iladioamado Official Facebook]''' * '''[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_zg4BHQ0i0WQk14AkpjVLQ Official Youtube Channel]''' * '''[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm4113369/ Iládio Amado at the IMDb] ([[Internet Movie Database]])''' * '''[https://soundcloud.com/iladioamado Iládio Amado at SoundCloud]'''

page.title: Institute for the International Education of Students

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP;add/change/refine category; MOS fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{advert|date=May 2013}} {{notability|Organizations|date=May 2013}} {{primary sources|date=May 2013}} }} {{Infobox organization |name=IES Abroad |logo= LogoTrademarked.jpg |logo_size= 220px |type=[[Nonprofit organization|Not-for-profit]]
([[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] [[Tax exemption|exemption status]]): [[501(c)(3)]] |founded_date=1950{{cite web|url=https://www.iesabroad.org/IES/About_IES/aboutIES.html |title=About Us | IES Abroad | Study Abroad |publisher=IES Abroad |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}} |founder=Paul Koutny, Clarence Giese, Alberta Giese |location=[[Chicago|Chicago, IL]], ''Headquarters'' |origins= |key_people= Dr. Mary Dwyer
''President & [[chief executive officer|CEO]]'' |area_served=Global |focus=[[Education]], [[Study abroad in the United States|Study Abroad]], [[Intercultural competence|Intercultural leadership]] |method= |revenue= |endowment= |num_employees= 250+ |owner= |Non-profit_slogan= |former name=''The Institute of European Studies'' |homepage=[https://www.IESabroad.org/ www.IESabroad.org] |footnotes = Member of [[NAFSA: Association of International Educators|NAFSA]], [[Forum on education abroad]], and Diversity Abroad }} The '''Institute for the International Education of Students''', or IES Abroad, is a [[non-profit organization|non-profit]] [[study abroad organization]] that administers [[study abroad]] programs for U.S. college-aged students.{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-287390179.html|title=Educators discuss strategies to diversify pool of study-abroad students|last=Hu|first=Helen|date=12 April 2012|work=Diverse Issues in Higher Education {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=6 August 2013}} Founded in 1950 as the Institute of European Studies, the organization has since been renamed to reflect additional offerings in [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Oceania]], and [[Latin America]]. The organization now provides more than 125+ programs in 19 countries and 33 cities. Over 115,000 students have studied abroad on IES Abroad programs since its founding, with more than 5,700 students studying abroad each year. IES Abroad has an Academic Consortium composed of over 200 academic institutions.{{cite book|last1=Twombly|first1=Susan|last2=Salisbury|first2=Mark|last3=Turmanut|first3=Shannon|title=Study Abroad in a New Global Century|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=C-n5kCFbNR8C&lpg=PA34&dq=IES%20Abroad&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q=IES%20Abroad&f=false|year=2012|publisher=Wiley|page=34}} It offers over $3 million in [[scholarships]] to help finance qualified students abroad.{{cite web|url=https://www.iesabroad.org/IES/Scholarships_and_Aid/financialAid.html |title=Scholarships | IES Abroad | Study Abroad |publisher=IES Abroad |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}} In accordance with its [[Mission statement|mission]] and vision statement, IES Abroad highlights cultural immersion through the use of [[homestay]]s and field trips to "[promote] the development of interculturally-competent leaders."{{cite web|url=https://www.iesabroad.org/IES/About_IES/mission.html |title=Mission & Vision | IES Abroad | Study Abroad |publisher=IES Abroad |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}} IES Abroad's services include pre-departure advising, [[Visa (document)|visa]] assistance, alumni mentors, and safety plans at Centers abroad.{{cite web|url=https://www.iesabroad.org/study-abroad/about/safety |title=Safety | IES Abroad}} IES Abroad has a diversity initiative{{cite web|url=https://www.iesabroad.org/IES/Diversity/diversity.html |title=Diversity Abroad | IES Abroad | Study Abroad |publisher=IES Abroad |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}} and a green initiative.{{cite web|url=http://www.iesabroad.org/study-abroad/about/green-initiatives |title=Go Green Initiative | IES Abroad | Study Abroad |publisher=IES Abroad |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}} == History == IES Abroad offered its first program in September 1950, when Paul Koutny, an [[Austrians|Austrian]] student living in the [[United States|U.S.]] on a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] scholarship, brought American students to live and study in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] for a year.{{cite web|url=http://www.iesabroad.org/study-abroad/about/history |title=History | IES Abroad}} Two of the students from the original program, newlyweds Clarence and Alberta Giese, returned after the program inspired to help other students study abroad. From their [[Chicago]] home, they worked with Koutny to recruit more students and send them abroad.Salts, Josh (20 Jan 2011). "[http://www.reformer.com/localnews/ci_17142553?source=rss Educational Pioneers]" ''Battleboro Reformer''. Retrieved 6 August 2013. IES Abroad developed a Model Assessment Practice {{cite web|url=http://www.iesabroad.org/study-abroad/advisors-faculty/ies-abroad-map |title=MAP Series | IES Abroad}} in 1999 as a framework for the design, development, and evaluation of programs of study abroad. This program formed the basis for the standards of the [[Forum on education abroad|Forum on Education Abroad]] adopted by the field.Gillespie, Joan et al., "[https://books.google.com/books?id=N4ifF9FfwcEC&pg=PA457&lpg=PA457&dq=%22ies+abroad%22&source=bl&ots=pVhUnFn7Z3&sig=MLDKhntUq0Kvv8mPcwY5qW-g8Bg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h7AFUoiXLIjUyQHM_oCwAQ&ved=0CFsQ6AEwBTgo#v=onepage&q=%22ies%20abroad%22&f=false Holistic Student Learning and Development Abroad: The IES 3-D Program Model]," ''The Handbook of Practice and Research in Study Abroad'' at 457 (2009). In 2010, IES Abroad was the first third-party provider to receive the [[Forum on education abroad|Forum on Education Abroad]]'s Category 2b Quality Improvement Designation, which involves independent reviewers using evaluation systems to make program improvements. Forum on Education Abroad (2010). "[http://www.forumea.org/quip-aboutquip.cfm Quality Improvement Program (QUIP) for Education Abroad]". Retrieved 6 August 2013. ==Notable alumni== *[[Donald Hopkins]] *[[Willard Huyck]] *[[John Irving]] *[[Michael Isikoff]] *[[Meghan Markle]] *[[Charles E. Merrill, Jr.]] *[[David Muir]] *[[Janet Napolitano]] *[[Sonia Nazario]] *[[Adrienne S. O'Neal]] *[[Mark Shriver]] *[[Daniel Quinn]] ==See also== *[[NAFSA: Association of International Educators]] *[[Institute of International Education]] *[[Forum on education abroad]] *[[Study abroad in the United States]] *[[Study abroad organization]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.IESabroad.org/ IES Abroad website] * [http://www.studyabroadphoto.com/ IES Abroad's Study Abroad Photo of the Day] * [http://www.diversityabroad.com/ Diversity Abroad] {{DEFAULTSORT:Institute For The International Education Of Students}} [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:International educational organizations]] [[Category:Study abroad programs]] [[Category:1950 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1950]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]]

'''Jeanine Basinger''' (born 3 February 1936), a [[film historian]], was for many years the Corwin-Fuller Professor of Film Studies and Founder and Curator of The Cinema Archives at [[Wesleyan University]], [[Middletown, Connecticut|Middletown]], [[Connecticut]]. ==Career== She is also a trustee emeritus of the [[American Film Institute]],<ref name="nbrmp">[http://www.nbrmp.org/newsevents/JeanineBasinger.cfm "Wesleyan Film Chair Jeanine Basinger to Join the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures Board of Directors"]. ''[[National Board of Review of Motion Pictures]]'', accessed October 20, 2011.</ref> a member of the Steering Committee of the National Center for Film and Video Preservation, and one of the Board of Advisors for the Association of Independent Video and Filmmakers. On February 11, 2005, she was named to the board of directors of the [[National Board of Review of Motion Pictures]].<ref name="nbrmp"/> She has a BS and MS from [[South Dakota State University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wesleyan.edu/filmstudies/faculty/index.html|title=Faculty|work=wesleyan.edu}}</ref> ==Legacy== Basinger has been described as "one of the most important film scholars alive today."<ref>Pulle, Goug (August 12, 2011). [http://www.elpasotimes.com/entertainment/ci_18663085 "Experts' insights add to Plaza Classic Film Festival experience"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120911173036/http://www.elpasotimes.com/entertainment/ci_18663085 |date=2012-09-11 }}. ''[[El Paso Times]]'', accessed October 18, 2011.</ref> Among other accomplishments, she is credited with having built Wesleyan's Film Studies program into one of the ten best film schools in the world.<ref>Appelo, Tim (July 27, 2011). [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/25-best-film-schools-rankings-215714 "The 25 Best Film Schools Rankings"]. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', accessed October 18, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118059843?refCatId=18 Women's Impact Report 2012: Academics] Jeanine Basinger, Film Studies Chair, Wesleyan U. Variety. By Anneta Konstantinides. 4 October 2012. Retrieved 13 October 2012.</ref> "A shockingly disproportionate number of Hollywood movers and shakers" are graduates of the program.<ref>[http://roth.blogs.wesleyan.edu/files/2008/09/wesleyanvanityfair.pdf "Wesleyan's Entertaining Class"]. ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', Oct. 2008, Issue 578, p180-180, 1p, 32 Color Photographs.</ref> Graduates include [[Akiva Goldsman]], [[Joss Whedon]], [[Michael Bay]], [[Paul Weitz (filmmaker)|Paul Weitz]], [[Laurence Mark]], [[Paul Schiff]], [[Gary Walkow]], [[Alex Kurtzman]], [[Bruce Eric Kaplan]], [[Toby Emmerich]], [[Nick Meyer]], [[Marc Shmuger]], [[Rick Nicita]], [[Bradley Fuller]], [[Dana Delany]], [[Stephen Schiff]], [[Rodger Grossman]], [[Toni Ross]], [[Bradley Whitford]], [[Domenica Cameron-Scorsese]], [[Liz Garcia]], [[Marc Longenecker]], [[Jon Turteltaub]], [[Owen Renfroe]], [[Jeffrey Lane]], [[Zak Penn]], [[Jeremy Arnold]] and [[Miguel Arteta]].<ref>Loewenstein, Lael (March 27, 2008). [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117983035?refCatId=2870 "Basinger's students make their mark"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', accessed October 20, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117983033.html?categoryid=2870&cs=1 "Students and peers praise Basinger"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' (March 27, 2008), accessed October 18, 2011.</ref>
She has appeared in numerous documentaries, and also in a dramatic role in ''A Better Way to Die'' (2000). In 2006 she participated in ''[[Wanderlust (2006 film)|Wanderlust]]'', a documentary film on [[road movies]] and their effect on [[American culture]].
==Awards== *1996 Wesleyan Binswanger Prize for Excellence in Teaching<ref name="nbrmp"/> *1999 [[National Board of Review of Motion Pictures|National Board of Review]]'s William K. Everson Prize for [[Film History]] for ''Silent Stars''<ref>[http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/awards.cfm?award=William%20K.%20Everson%20Award%20for%20Film%20History "William K. Everson Award for Film History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305144012/http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/awards.cfm?award=William%20K.%20Everson%20Award%20For%20Film%20History |date=2016-03-05 }}. ''National Board of Review of Motion Pictures'', accessed October 21, 2011.</ref> *2005 Governor's Arts and Tourism Award from the Connecticut Commission on Culture and Tourism<ref>[http://www.wesleyan.edu/newsletter/achieve/2006/achievements2006.html "The Wesleyan Connection's Achievements 2006"]. Weslyan University newsletter, accessed October 18, 2011.</ref> *Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from the American Film Institute on June 7, 2006<ref>Rich, Katey (May 5, 2006). [http://wesleyanargus.com/2006/05/05/basinger-to-receive-honorary-degree/ "Basinger to receive honorary degree"]. ''The Wesleyan Argus'', accessed October 20, 2011.</ref> *2008 Theatre Library Association Award for ''The Star Machine''<ref>[http://www.tla-online.org/awards/bookawards/tlaaward/winners.html "Theatre Library Association Award - Winners, 1974-2009"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105222137/http://www.tla-online.org/awards/bookawards/tlaaward/winners.html |date=2011-11-05 }}. ''Theatre Library Association'', accessed October 21, 2011.</ref> *2013 Wesleyan Binswanger Prize for Excellence in Teaching
==Works==
===Books=== *''The World War II Combat Film: Anatomy of a Genre'' (1985, 2003) *''Anthony Mann: A Critical Study'' *''The ''It's a Wonderful Life'' Book'' *''Shirley Temple'' (1975) *''Lana Turner'' (1976) *''Gene Kelly'' (1976) *''A Woman's View: How Hollywood Spoke to Women 1930-1960'' (1993) *''American Cinema: 100 Years of Filmmaking'' (companion book for a [[PBS]] series). *''Silent Stars'' (1999) *''The Star Machine'', [[Alfred A. Knopf]] (2007) ({{ISBN|978-1-4000-4130-5}}). About the height of the [[studio system]] in the [[Classical Hollywood cinema#The Golden Age|Golden Age]] from the 1930s to the 1950s. *''I Do and I Don't: A History of Marriage in the Movies'' (2013)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.com/book/9369/i-do-and-i-dont-by-jeanine-basinger|title=I Do and I Don't by Jeanine Basinger - PenguinRandomHouse.com|work=PenguinRandomhouse.com}}</ref>
===Audio commentaries=== *''[[The Ghost and Mrs. Muir]]'', with film historian Kenneth Geist *''[[Gigi (1958 film)|Gigi]]'', with actress [[Leslie Caron]] *''[[In This Our Life]]'' *''[[It (1927 film)|It]]'' *''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' ([[The Criterion Collection|Criterion]] [[laserdisc]]) *''[[Jezebel (film)|Jezebel]]'' *''[[Laura (1944 film)|Laura]]'', with composer [[David Raksin]] *''[[The Philadelphia Story (film)|The Philadelphia Story]]'' *''[[Pearl Harbor (film)|Pearl Harbor]]'', with director [[Michael Bay]] *''[[Sergeant York (film)|Sergeant York]]'' *''[[The Tall T]]'' *''[[Three Coins in the Fountain (film)|Three Coins in the Fountain]]'' *''[[Week-End in Havana]]'' *''[[The Wild One]]''
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * [https://wesep.wesleyan.edu/cgi-perl/faculty/faculty_page/faculty_page.cgi/?faculty=jbasinger Wesleyan Faculty Page] (accessed 30 Nov 2014) * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/jeanine_basinger/biography.php Bio on Rotten Tomatotes] * [http://www.poemhunter.com/quotations/famous.asp?people=Jeanine%20Basinger Quotations from Jeanine Basinger] (accessed 16 June 2006) * {{IMDb name|id=0059903}} (accessed 16 June 2006) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130610003837/http://www.wnyc.org/shows/lopate/2013/jun/03/marriage-and-movies/ WNYC Leonard Lopate June 3, 2013 interview on marriage and the movies.] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/10/books/review/i-do-and-i-dont-by-jeanine-basinger.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 NY Times Review March 10, 2013 review of "I Do and I Don't"] *[https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-02-01/opinions/36681767_1_marriage-jeanine-basinger-film-historian Washington Post Feb. 1, 2013 Review "I Do and I Don't"]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Basinger, Jeanine}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American curators]] [[Category:Film educators]] [[Category:American film historians]] [[Category:Film theorists]] [[Category:Wesleyan University faculty]]

revision.comment: /* top */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[Open-source software|open source]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Software | logo = lams-logo.svg | screenshot = LAMS-Author.jpg | screenshot size = 300px | caption = LAMS Authoring Environment in [[Mozilla Firefox|Firefox]] | collapsible = | author = LAMS Foundation | developer = | released = | latest release version = 3.0.2 | latest release date = June 2018 | latest preview version = 3.0.1 | latest preview date = December 2017 | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = [[WildFly|WildFly Application Server]] | size = | language = 32 languages <ref>LAMS Internationalization website http://lamscommunity.org/i18n</ref> | genre = [[Elearning|Online Education]], [[IMS Learning Design|Learning Design]] | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL v2]] | website = https://lamsfoundation.org/ }} '''LAMS''', the Learning Activity Management System, is an [[Open-source software|open source]] [[Instructional design|Learning Design]] system for designing, managing and delivering online collaborative learning activities. It provides teachers with an intuitive visual authoring environment for creating sequences of learning activities. These activities can include a range of individual tasks, small group work and whole class activities based on both content and collaboration. LAMS is 'inspired' by the concept and principles of [[IMS Learning Design]].<ref>Learning Design inspiration - CETIS http://zope.cetis.ac.uk/content2/20031105152011</ref>
LAMS is developed in collaboration with LAMS Foundation and a number of educational institutions around the world. LAMS has been developed since 2003.<ref>Implementing learning design: the learning activity management system (LAMS) {{cite web |url=http://www.ascilite.org.au/conferences/adelaide03/docs/pdf/593.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706124109/http://ascilite.org.au/conferences/adelaide03/docs/pdf/593.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref>. LAMS International (Sydney) and LAMS Education Asia (Singapore) are commercial companies that provide development and support services for the LAMS platform.
== Community == The LAMS community website is a global community website for teachers and developers who use the LAMS software. As of March 2018, the LAMS Community had over 12000 members across 80 countries sharing 3750 sequences (downloaded 32252, previewed 83102 times) and 8592 discussion forum postings.<ref>For statistics for LAMS Community, March, 2018, http://lamscommunity.org/stats</ref>
LAMS creates "digital lesson plans" that can be run online with students, as well as shared among teachers. The LAMS Community allows teachers to share and adapt digital lesson plans, and discuss their experiences of using LAMS. Teachers, trainers and professors can find digital lessons plans that are freely available to use and adapt, and they can share their own and adaptations. There is a Greek LAMS community.
=== LAMS Central ===
The LAMS Community has a central repository of learning designs (LAMS Central Repository). These are LAMS sequences shared by teachers and practitioners that use LAMS in their teaching. The subjects of these designs vary widely, from Higher Ed Science subjects to basic k-12.
== Awards and recognitions ==
LAMS in conjunction with the associated LAMS Community won a Gold Award and Best Learning System at the IMS Global Learning Consortium's Learning Impact Awards (LIAs) in May 2009.<ref>IMS Learning Impact Awards 2009 http://www.imsglobal.org/pressreleases/pr090514.html</ref>
== Available versions ==
As of June 2018, the current stable version of LAMS is 3.0.2<ref>Download links and building instructions are provided on the LAMS Documentation Wiki at https://wiki.lamsfoundation.org/display/lams/Downloads</ref> Version 3.0 is a major release that introduces a responsive web design, drops the need to have Adobe Flash Player, updated all its tech stack and adds significant feature and technical improvements. <ref>LAMS 3.0 feature list https://wiki.lamsfoundation.org/display/lams/LAMS+3.0+Feature+List</ref>
LAMS version 3.1 is available as beta release (Oct 2018).
== LAMS integrations with other LMS==
LAMS can be integrated with any LMS system that implement [[Learning Tools Interoperability|IMS LTI]] as a consumer. However, IMS LTI 1.2 has some important limitations, therefore native integration with other popular LMSs are available for:
* [[Moodle]] version 2.x and 3.x * [[Sakai Project|Sakai]] * [[Blackboard Inc.|Blackboard]] * [[OpenACS|.LRN]] * [[WebCT]] * [[SharePoint]] * [[OLAT]]
LAMS is both a IMS LTI 1.3 consumer and service provider, including Deep Linking and Membership extensions.
== LAMS Tool Contract ==
The LAMS Tool Contract is an architecture to allow Tool Interoperability across [[Learning Management System]]s (LMS). It allows tools (web applications) to become "pluggable" in any [[learning management system|LMS]].<ref>LAMS "Tools Contract". TenCompetence Workshop. UPF - Barcelona. 21 de Junio 2007. Ernie Ghiglione & James Dalziel {{cite web |url=http://www.tencompetence.org/files/Barcelona/presentations/session1/Ghiglione.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822223330/http://www.tencompetence.org/files/Barcelona/presentations/session1/Ghiglione.pdf |archivedate=2007-08-22 |df= }}</ref> The LAMS Tool Contract is the underlying architecture of LAMS and currently tools from other platforms like Moodle and dotLRN can be used within LAMS.<ref>Tool Adapters http://wiki.lamsfoundation.org/display/lams/Tool+Adapters</ref>
== Conferences ==
These international conferences are academic conferences where papers submitted are peer-reviewed by members of the conference committee. The main topics of this conferences are LAMS and Learning Design and are mainly in English (although there has been one in Spanish). The first LAMS Conference was in Sydney Australia in December, 2006.<ref>The First International LAMS Conference http://lamsfoundation.org/lams2006/</ref> Usually there are two conferences a year, one in Australia and one in Europe or Asia.
* The 1st International LAMS Conference. Sydney, Australia, December 2006 <ref>The 1st International LAMS Conference http://lamsfoundation.org/lams2006/</ref> * 2007 European LAMS Conference. UK, July 2007 <ref>2007 European LAMS Conference http://www.lamsfoundation.org/lams2007/</ref> * The 2nd International LAMS Conference. Sydney, Australia, November 2007 <ref>The 2nd International LAMS Conference http://lams2007sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * Conferencia Iberoamericana LAMS 2008 / 2008 European LAMS Conference. Spain, June 2008 <ref>Conferencia Iberoamericana LAMS 2008 / 2008 European LAMS Conference http://lams2008.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * The 3rd International LAMS & Learning Design Conference. Sydney, Australia, December 2008 <ref>The 3rd International LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2008sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * 2009 European LAMS & Learning Design Conference. UK, July 2009 <ref>2009 European LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2009.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * The 4th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference. Sydney, December, 2009 <ref>4th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference in Sydney, December 2009 http://lams2009sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * 2010 European LAMS & Learning Design Conference. [[Oxford University]], UK, July 2010 <ref>2010 European LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2010.lamsfoundation.org</ref> * The 5th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference. Sydney, December 2010 <ref>5th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2010sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * 2011 Asia Pacific LAMS & Learning Design. Singapore, June, 2011 <ref>2011 Asia Pacific LAMS Conference http://lams2011.lamsfoundation.org</ref> * The 6th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference, Sydney, December 2011 <ref>6th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2011sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref> * The 7th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference, Sydney, December 2012 <ref>7th International LAMS & Learning Design Conference http://lams2012sydney.lamsfoundation.org/</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Maria Lowenstein''' (April 4, 1894 - October 29, 1982) was an American artist.<ref name="NorthDenverTribune">{{cite web|title=Honoring the remarkable life and artwork of Maria Lowenstein|url=http://www.northdenvertribune.com/2013/10/honoring-the-remarkable-life-and-artwork-of-maria-lowenstein/|website=North Denver Tribune|accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref>
==Life== Lowenstein was born Maria Lilli Margarete Baetge in [[Estonia]].<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/maria-lilli-margarete-baetge</ref> In 1914 in [[Helsinki]], she married architect Erich Steinberg, by whom she had a daughter, Karin, (1915-2014).<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/maria-lilli-margarete-baetge</ref> After fleeing from the tumult of the [[Russian Revolution]], Maria moved to [[Berlin, Germany|Berlin]], where her husband, Erich Steinberg, died in 1920.<ref>http://duarchives.coalliance.org/repositories/2/resources/565</ref> In 1925, Maria married the Jewish German dermatologist Max Loewenstein; their son, Henry, was born that same year.<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/dr--max-loewenstein</ref> Among the friends of Max and Maria was the composer [[Kurt Weill]].<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/henry--heinrich--loewenstein</ref>
Having previously studied at the [[Hermitage Museum]] in [[St. Petersburg]], Maria refined her artistic talents at the Institute of Fine Arts in Berlin.<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/maria-lilli-margarete-baetge</ref>
Although she saw her son to safety in 1938 during the [[Kindertransport]], she and her husband and daughter stayed in Berlin during the war, where she was involved in the [[Rosenstrasse protests]] of wives of Jewish men. <ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/survival-in-berlin--1939-1945/rosenstrasse-protest</ref> Lowenstein emigrated to the United States in 1946 and settled first in [[Williamsport, Pennsylvania]], where one of her students was [[Barrie Karp]]. Max Loewenstein died in 1948.<ref>http://digital.library.du.edu/librariespresents/exhibits/show/the-lowenstein-family/family-heritage/dr--max-loewenstein</ref> Later, Maria settled in [[Denver, Colorado|Denver]] where her son, Henry (1925-2014), became prominent on the theatre scene as a producer and set designer.<ref>https://www.denvercenter.org/blog-posts/news-center/2014/10/07/henry-lowenstein-father-of-denver-theatre-passes-away</ref>
== External links == * [http://www.rosenstrasse-protest.de/texte/texte_stoltzfus.html The Women's Rosenstraße Protest in Nazi Berlin, Nathan Stoltzfus] * [http://duarchives.coalliance.org/repositories/2/resources/565 Maria Lowenstein and the Holocaust ]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = National Shakespeare Conservatory | image = | motto = | established = 1974-1998 | type = [[Acting]] | locale = | grades = | head_name = Founders | head = Philip Meister
Albert Schoemann
Mario Siletti | head_name2 = | head2 = | city = [[New York City]] | state = [[New York (state)|New York]] | country = [[United States]] | students = 45-100 | faculty = 15-20 | athletics = | school_colors = | mascot = | free_label = Length of Program | free = Two years and 8 week Summer Program | free_label2 = | free2 = | free_label3 = | free3 = | website = }} The '''National Shakespeare Conservatory''' was an [[acting]] school in [[New York City]], offering a two-year certificate program and an eight-week summer training program. The Conservatory was founded in 1974 by Philip Meister, Albert Schoemann and Mario Siletti.{{cite web | title = Mario Siletti; Acting Teacher, 65 | publisher = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1991-01-21 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3DB1E31F932A15752C0A967958260 | accessdate = 2007-03-19}} ==History== The Conservatory was an offshoot of the National Shakespeare Company, a professional acting company that toured productions of Shakespeare and the classics to colleges and universities throughout the US and Canada. The Summer Conservatory was first offered at the Byrdcliffe Theatre in Woodstock, N.Y. in 1974, and moved its facilities to Kerhonkson, N.Y. in 1978, where it continued summer operations until 1998. The Conservatory expanded to a Two Year Program in New York City in 1977, and was situated in the National Shakespeare Company's brownstone studios and offices on West 51 Street near 9th Avenue in Manhattan, along with The Cubiculo, an off-off-Broadway theatre, also owned and operated by the National Shakespeare Company. After Meister's death in 1982, Siletti and Schoemann established The Conservatory as a separate entity from the National Shakespeare Company, and moved the operation of the Two Year Program to lower Broadway in Soho. The National Shakespeare Conservatory was one of the first independent professional actor training programs in the U.S. to become an institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Theatre in 1978; a status gained only through the peer review process of accreditation. The Conservatory's training emphasized classical plays, utilizing a broad array of contemporary acting techniques – physical, vocal and internal – that enabled the voice and body to support the actor's internal choices. The integration of the physical and vocal with internal techniques with a strong classical base was the hallmark of Conservatory's intensive training. The Summer Program and the first year of training in the Two Year Program was devoted to intensive classes in scene study, acting technique, Shakespeare, movement, dance, voice, improvisation and music. The second year was devoted to rigorous advanced study in the same areas. As part of the curriculum, the second year included a one-person show and [[Off-Off-Broadway]] showcases. Many of the National Shakespeare Conservatory teachers were professional actors recruited by Meister, Schoemann and Siletti to serve as faculty, beginning their teaching careers at The Conservatory, and subsequently teaching at the [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]], its undergraduate studio program at New York University, and other colleges and universities. Beginning in 1994, the US Department of Education raised its requirement for the National Shakespeare Conservatory to post a Letter of Credit in order to continue participation in the federal student aid programs. Because of The Conservatory's quality of accreditation review, low student loan default rate and consistent long term operation as a non-profit organization, The Conservatory considered the amount of the Letter of Credit excessive and contested it in federal court. After a two-year battle with the USDE the federal judge ruled against the school. The National Shakespeare Conservatory then offered to post the Letter of Credit. The Department of Education refused to accept the Letter of Credit from the National Shakespeare Conservatory, and terminated the Conservatory's participation in federal student financial assistance programs, based on the school's failure to provide a sufficient letter of credit in 1996.{{Cite web | last = [[United States Department of Education]] | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = In the matter of National Shakespeare Conservatory, Respondent. | date = 1996-02-27 | url = http://www.ed-oha.org/cases/1995-133-st.html | accessdate = 2007-03-19 | postscript = }} As a consequence, the school ceased operations of the Two Year training program that fall. The Summer Conservatory continued to operate for the next two years. In 1996 in addition to its training program, it provided free outdoor performances of Shakespeare in municipal parks in upstate New York, under the banner Catskill Shakespeare until the school closed in late 1998. == Faculty == * Philip Meister - Artistic Director and Master Acting Teacher. Deceased. * Mario Siletti - Head of Acting, Also headed faculty of [[Stella Adler Conservatory]]. Deceased. * James Tripp - Master Acting Teacher, current Head of Acting and Master Teacher at the [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]]. * Peter Lobdell - Movement, Currently teaches at Amherst. Physical coach for the original [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions of ''[[The Elephant Man (play)|The Elephant Man]]'' and ''[[Equus (play)|Equus]]''. *Alice Winston, Master Acting Teacher. Deceased. * Joanne Munisteri - Movement, Speech, Acting. * Lisa Jacobson - Movement, Acting. Currently teaches at AMDA. * Robert Perillo - A Master Voice Coach in New York City and director with such companies as Jean Cocteau Repertory in New York City. * Joan Evans - Movement, Currently teaches at the [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]] and New York University. *Casey Kizziah - Acting, voice and speech. Deceased. *Angela Vitale - Voice and Speech, Currently teaches at the [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]]. *[[Sandra Cavanaugh]] - Voice and Speech and body Alignment, currently artistic director of New Heritage Theatre Company. *Jane Armitage *Eloise Watt - Shakespeare *Fay Simpson - Movement *Joseph Siravo - Voice and speech *Marc Falcone - Music and Sight Singing *Gerard Rusak - Voice, Operatic vocalization *Gregory Wolfe - The Sonnet Project(summer only) *Mark Zeller - Voice and Speech *Dana Zeller-Alexis - Acting *Robert Blumenfeld - Dialects *Tanis Hugel - Movement *William Joseph McBride - Movement-Stage Combat-Stage Management == Administration == *Albert Schoemann - Director *Pamela Hare – Administrative Director/Registrar ==Notable alumni== *[[Suzanne Graff]] *[[Diana Scarwid]] *[[Annabelle Gurwitch]] *[[Park Overall]] *[[Miguel Perez (American actor)|Miguel Perez]] *[[James Wolfe]] *[[Wayne LeGette]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|40.7641|-73.9883|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=title}} [[Category:Theatre in New York (state)]] [[Category:Drama schools in the United States]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct drama schools]] [[Category:Defunct universities and colleges in New York (state)]] [[Category:1974 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1998 disestablishments in New York (state)]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = North Central Association of Colleges and Schools |image = NCACS logo.png |image_border = |size = |caption = NCA logo |map = |msize = 150px |mcaption = NCA operating area |abbreviation = NCA |formation = 1895 |successor = [[AdvancED]]
[[Higher Learning Commission]] |status = Defunct |purpose = Educational accreditation |headquarters = [[Tempe, Arizona]]
[[Chicago, Illinois]] |region_served = [[Arkansas]], [[Arizona]], [[Colorado]], [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]], [[Iowa]], [[Kansas]], [[Michigan]], [[Minnesota]], [[Missouri]], [[Nebraska]], [[New Mexico]], [[North Dakota]], [[Ohio]], [[Oklahoma]], [[South Dakota]], [[West Virginia]], [[Wisconsin]], [[Wyoming]] |main_organ = Board of Directors |affiliations = [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation|CHEA]] |website = [http://www.northcentralassociation.org www.northcentralassociation.org] }} The '''North Central Association of Colleges and Schools''' ('''NCA'''), also known as the '''North Central Association''', was a membership organization, consisting of colleges, universities, and schools in 19 U.S. states engaged in [[educational accreditation]]. It was one of six [[regional accreditation]] bodies in the U.S. and its [[Higher Learning Commission]] was recognized by the [[United States Department of Education]] and the [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]] (CHEA) as a regional accreditor for [[higher education]] institutions.[http://www.chea.org/pdf/CHEA_USDE_AllAccred.pdf Recognized Accrediting Organizations], Council for Higher Education Accreditation, accessed October 8, 2010 The organization was dissolved in 2014.{{cite web |url=https://www.hlcommission.org/About-the-Commission/about-hlc.html |title=About the Higher Learning Commission |publisher=[[Higher Learning Commission]] |date=2015 |accessdate=December 18, 2015}} The primary and secondary education accreditation functions of the association have been merged into [[AdvancED]] with the postsecondary education accreditation functions vested in the [[Higher Learning Commission]]. ==See also== *[[List of recognized accreditation associations of higher learning]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.northcentralassociation.org/ Official website] [[Category:School accreditors]] [[Category:1895 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:School accreditors in Chicago]] [[Category:College and university associations and consortia in the United States]] [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:2014 disestablishments in Illinois]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox University |name = Open University of Cyprus |native_name = Ανοικτό Πανεπιστήμιο Κύπρου |image_name = Open University of Cyprus (OUC).svg |image_size = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 2002 |type = Public |endowment = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = Prof. Socratis Katsikas |chancellor = |president = |vice-president = |staff = |students = 4200 (2013-2014 academic year) |city = Nicosia |country = Cyprus |website = http://www.ouc.ac.cy }}
'''Open University of Cyprus''' is a '''public Higher Education Institution,''' operating under the effective control of the Ministry of Education and Culture of the Republic of Cyprus. Established in 2002, OUC is the country’s only University '''devoted entirely to open and distance education and lifelong learning'''. OUC offers '''interdisciplinary, career-oriented and accredited Bachelor’s, Master’s and PhD degree programmes''' in both ‘classical’ and ‘cutting edge’ scientific areas.
==Mission==
Open University of Cyprus aspires to provide students with lifelong learning opportunities and higher education degrees useful to start or advance their professional careers, and fulfill their personal aspirations and goals. The University aims to combine its international reach and flexible operations and structure, using both to support the State’s vision to establish Cyprus as a regional centre for education, scientific research and innovation, a hub for international scholars and students alike. Towards this direction, OUC expands its network of collaborators and establishes strong partnerships with Universities and research institutions in Cyprus, the broader region and beyond, promoting educational and research cooperation and mobility of students and staff.
==Educational Methodology and Programmes of Study==
Open University of Cyprus is a dedicated open and distance learning University. Its educational technology, in combination with modern teaching and learning methods supported by multi-format educational materials, '''respond to the diverse needs of its students, allowing them to study wherever and whenever they wish, using any digital platform. ''' Accordingly, OUC’s distance education and '''blended learning methodology''' differs from conventional classroom-based education, mainly because it allows '''students''' to '''complete their studies and obtain their degree, breaking down the rigid barriers of traditional education''', without physically attending scheduled lectures, and – in case students are already employed – without disrupting work routines or leaving their workplace.
eLearning Platform - eClass
The University’s main educational tool is the '''eLearning Platform eClass''' that facilitates online teaching and learning through the establishment of '''virtual classrooms,''' supports '''lecture capture, live and video on demand lectures and tutorials,''' and integrates '''real-time and asynchronous collaboration tools.''' Concisely, OUC’s eLearning Platform is a comprehensive and constantly evolving eLearning system backing the educational process across all its phases.
Students use eClass to:
*access their course materials, *organise their study calendars, *communication with tutors and fellow students, *submit their formative assignments and coursework, and *receive feedback on their progress.
In a true collaborative environment, the eLearning platform also supports live interaction and direct contact with academics, peers and fellow students. The synchronous collaboration (virtual classrooms, live streaming) and asynchronous (forums, instant messaging) communication tools are fully utilised by experienced and dedicated academic staff, offering '''effective and interactive academic support,''' guidance and advice. Moreover, virtual labs have further enhanced the University’s educational capabilities in supporting and offering high quality innovative programmes in any subject.
Despite being ‘distance’ in essence, learning experience at OUC is complemented by academics-students group tutorials that are scheduled throughout the academic year and, while not mandatory, they play a key supporting role in educational processes. These '''tutorials''' are '''organised either with physical presence or are conducted online''' using ''' eClass virtual classes, and are academically challenging and rigorous. To ensure the integrity of OUC degrees and examination processes, students are required to attend in person (at examination centres in Cyprus, Greece or elsewhere under certain conditions) the final written exams, which count towards a significant percentage of their overall grade.
==Study at OUC==
OUC’s extensive range of Programmes of Study covers subject areas in undergraduate (BA, BSc) and postgraduate level (MA, MSc, PhD) offered in Greek and English by its three Faculties:
* [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/s1 Humanities and Social Sciences] * [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/s2 Pure and Applied Sciences] * [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/s3 Economics and Management]
The detailed list of Programmes of Study and related courses offered by Open University of Cyprus can be found [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/university/programme here]
==Administration==
OUC is a State University, and its main decision-making bodies are the following:
* The Council * The Senate The Director of Administration and Finance is the head of the University’s administration, and acts as Secretary of the Senate and the Council.
==Operating Law==
OUC operating Law may be found at the [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/ website] of the University
==Links== * [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/ OUC website] * [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/troposfoit/methoapky OUC Educational Methodology] * [http://www.ouc.ac.cy/web/guest/ypfoit/platforma eLearning Platform]
